MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: I would like to make an announcement on the merger debate. It has become increasingly evident during the last 8 days that in relation to the amendment proposed by the Member for Queenstown to the merger motion moved by the Minister for Labour, all points of view appear already to have been advanced and to have been thoroughly discussed.

    As a result, it has been distinctly noticed that certain Members on both sides of the House have been unable to offer any new arguments and have, in fact, repeated the arguments used by other Members. While a certain amount of repetition is inevitable in a debate, constant repetition of the same theme and the same arguments becomes tedious and is not permitted.

    I have had occasion to refer to the relevant Standing Order on this point, and, as a further reminder to Honourable Members, I propose, to read that Standing Order again. It is Standing Order No. 54 and reads as follows:-

    '54. The Speaker or the Chairman, after having drawn attention to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition either of his own arguments or of the arguments used by other Members in debate, may direct him to discontinue his speech.'

Column: 970



    The extent to which the debate on this matter has been drawn out is largely due to repetitions of Members' own arguments or the arguments used by other Members and if, in future, the repetitions become tedious, I shall find myself compelled, as I am bound to under the Standing Order, to direct the Member speaking to discontinue his speech. This I am always reluctant to do, more especially in this particular debate, which is one on a matter of such grave import to the peoples of Singapore and indeed to the peoples of the whole of the future Malaysia.

    At the same time, it is incumbent upon me as Speaker to ensure that the debate is kept within its proper bounds. With that in view, I called a meeting of Leaders of all Parties represented on the Opposition Benches, the independent Member on the Opposition Benches, the Leader of the House and the Government Whip in order to ascertain whether there could be some agreement whereby the conclusion of the present debate could be reached at the earliest possible moment.

    Certain devices are adopted in other Parliaments to bring proceedings to a speedy conclusion, but I need mention only two.

    Firstly, time limits may be placed on the length of speeches and, secondly, Members voluntarily subject themselves to self-discipline in relation to the time they should allow themselves and the substance of their speeches.

    A meeting of Members of the Opposition and the Leader of the House was held in my Chamber this morning and it was agreed that the second device would best meet the circumstances in the present debate. I invite Honourable Members to adopt the course suggested, that is to say, to subject themselves to self-discipline and so to see that their speeches are not unnecessarily lengthy and to avoid unnecessary repetitions.

GOVERNMENT CHINESE
SECONDARY IV EXAMINATION
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


2.33 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin) rose -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Yong, a ministerial statement?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Mr Speaker, Sir, today is the second last day of the Government Secondary IV Examination to be held in the Chinese medium. There are altogether three papers for today; the first paper being Additional Mathematics, in which 83 per cent of the candidates sat for the examination, and at the moment, the second paper, which is an optional paper in Geography, where 1,449 candidates out of a possible 2,521 candidates, that is, 58 per cent, are at present taking this paper.

    I should like to inform Members of this House that substitute papers will be prepared for those who have failed to attend the examinations for the past few days. They will be from Monday, 4th December, to Friday, 8th December, at three emergency centres; two next to the Ministry of Education namely Tanglin Boys' and Tanglin Girls' Schools and at the Teachers' Training College. I regret, however, having to draw the attention of Members to this afternoon's Press reports of further incidents this morning between picketers, students and parents in respect of those who wish to take the examinations in and out of examination halls.

    At noon today, representatives from the parents of students who are taking the examinations went to see my Parliamentary Secretary, Mr Lee Khoon Choy, and asked for police protection. I have just been informed of this, and my Parliamentary Secretary would like, Mr Speaker, Sir, to seek your permission and that of the House to move a motion under Standing Order 32.

EXAMINATIONS


2.35 p.m.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): Mr Speaker, Sir, the motion which I intend to move, signed by myself, the Minister for Education, the Member for Bukit Timah and the Member for Bukit Merah, is as follows:

    "That this House condemns the actions of the picketers in obstructing, intimidating or otherwise forcefully preventing students from taking their examinations, and in response to an appeal from parents of students who wish to take these examinations that they and their children should be afforded police protection, hereby resolves that this House supports any action by the police to protect students wishing to take their examinations to ensure that they are not intimidated or injured, and that the students and their parents who accompany them are given free passage and access into and out of all examination halls."

    Mr Speaker: Will the Parliamentary Secretary resume his seat for a minute? The Hon. the Parliamentary Secretary seeks leave of the House under Standing Order 32 to move the following motion:

    "That this House condemns the actions of the picketers in obstructing, intimidating or otherwise forcefully preventing students from taking their examinations, and in response to an appeal from parents of students who wish to take these examinations that they and their children should be afforded police protection, hereby resolves that this House supports any action by the police to protect students wishing to take their examinations to ensure that they are not intimidated or injured, and that the students and their parents who accompany them are given free passage and access into and out of all examination halls."

I might remind hon. Members of Standing Order 32, which reads:

    'Notice shall not be dispensed with in the case of a motion or in respect of any other proceeding for which notice is required except with the consent of the Speaker and the general assent of Members present.'

I give my consent. Is it the pleasure of hon. Members that this motion be moved?

On the 28th November we presented our opinion to the Minister for Education to ask for protection for those students who wish to take the Government common examination and to allow them to do so smoothly. The Minister for Education explained to them that because the Government wishes to avoid any conflict between the police and the students, it has, therefore, not asked the police to take any direct measure. During these few days the student strikers have resorted to force to stop the parents and students from entering the examination centres. For the safety of the students and the parents, we hone that the Legislative Assembly will also adopt measures, just as the Assembly has already approved a resolution to protect the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education. In the same way, it should also take steps to protect, or order the police to protect, the safety of students and free access to the examination centres.'

    After this representation and the meeting with the Minister for Education, the student strikers immediately dispersed. We believe that the Assembly can also approve a motion permitting the police to protect the students and their parents and to ensure that the student strikers will be kept restricted

MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)

(White Paper)


2.53 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [21st November, 1961] to Question [20th November, 1961],

    "That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya.".-(The Minister for Labour-Inche Ahmad bin Ibrahim).

    Which Amendment was,

Column: 976



    'To leave out from "a" in the second last line to the end and insert:

    "genuine merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth state and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal Citizens on Merger Day".'-(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to be left out, be left out."

    Mr Speaker: May I again draw the attention of hon. Members to the announcement I made earlier on in which I invited hon. Members to adopt one of two courses, i.e., to subject themselves to self-discipline and so to see that their speeches are not unnecessarily lengthy and to avoid unnecessary repetition. Copies of that announcement have been circulated.

    Miss Fung Yin Ching (Stamford)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, today I wish to criticise the Minister for Culture on two points. This will conclude my speech. What the Minister for Education said was published on 24th November, in the Sin Chew Jit Poh. The Minister for Education said that if the Barisan Sosialis leaders were sincere in fighting for a complete merger, then they should give up their fight for a full internal self-government -

    Mr Speaker: Order. Could it be made clear whether it is the Minister for Culture or the Minister for Education?

    Miss Fung Yin Ching(In Mandarin): The Minister for Culture. He said the aim of full internal self-government would negate the goal of complete merger. It would also cause racial conflict between Singapore and the Federation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I regret what the Minister for Culture said on this point. The stand of the Barisan Sosialis is very clear.

    We have made our proposals based on the present situation in Singapore:

    1. Complete merger. The content of this merger is that defence and external affairs will be vested in the hands of

Column: 977

the Federation Government. Singapore citizens on Merger Day should automatically become Federal citizens and there should be proportionate representation in the Federal Parliament.

    2. A form of confederation. The content is that defence and external affairs should be vested in the Federation by arrangement, but Singapore should have complete control of its internal affairs.

    3. If these two proposals are not acceptable to the Federation, then we should put aside our fight for merger and be prepared to negotiate with Britain for a self-governing Singapore by 1963.

    The Minister for Culture confused these two things. I feel that he either deliberately want-ed to confuse these two points or that he was not very clear about them. According to the analysis of the Minister for Culture, he said that if we did this, then we would be causing racial conflict between the two territories. I feel that the Minister for Culture wanted to distort our struggle through constitutional means as something which would create racial troubles. Secondly, the Minister for Culture said that according to the complete merger proposals made by the Barisan Sosialis, under which Singapore citizens would become Federal citizens, Singapore citizens would lose because they would have to accept the 4:1 ratio in the civil service, which is now applicable in the Federation. Therefore, we said that under the Barisan Sosialis proposals, they would have to accept the fact that privileges would be given to Malays. I wonder if, after merger, the Chinese in Singapore will lose and the Malays will benefit from these proposals. If this is so, why are our proposals not accepted by the Tunku? Does the Tunku want to fight for the interests of only the Chinese? I cannot understand it. The Government said that the motive behind our proposals on citizenship is that we want to contest an election in the Federation to sit in the Federal Parliament. I want to issue a challenge. If the citizens of Singapore will derive any

Column: 978

benefits from all this, after merger then we will make every sacrifice to achieve this aim.

    In conclusion, I support the amendment of the Barisan Sosialis because it proposes that the people of Singapore will get more democratic rights after merger.

3.02 p.m.

    Madam Hoe Puay Choo (Bras Basah)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the amendment proposed by the Member for Queenstown is not sincere. Let me now analyse the proposals. What is their object in proposing this amendment? The question of merger was raised and discussed when they were in the P.A.P. At that time, the Member for Queenstown did not object to our proposals on merger. Why does he now hold a different opinion on this question? This year, there have been some changes in our Party. The Members of the Barisan Sosialis launched a revolution to ensure for themselves the posts of Prime Minister and Ministers. I want to tell the people of Singapore that they do not want to fight for the benefit of the people. They want to fight for their own personal interest.

    During the Anson by-election, the break-away from our Party was mainly due to the demand of some trade unionists that they should have a discussion with Britain for full internal self-government. That was after our defeat in Hong Lim. That is why these politicians are now sitting on the other side. They have defected from our Party. Therefore, we can say that they are waverers. They do not have a firm stand. They are politicians.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, let me ask this question. What are the fears of the trade unions if merger is achieved? As far as I understand, the question of merger was raised by the Prime Minister of the Federation, Tunku Abdul Rahman. The P.A.P. then agreed to his proposals in principle, because this is what we have been fighting for since the inception of our Party. At that time, some colonial officers came to Singapore and this caused fears in the trade union movement.

They were afraid that if we merge with the Right-wing Federation, it would :then be disadvantageous to the Left-wing forces in Singapore. They have their problems and we understand this. In those days, they suspected that there was something fishy in the discussions held with the colonial officers. That is why the trade unionists started their fight against us. Mr Speaker, Sir, it was because of this that these opportunistic politicians were frightened. At that time, they thought that if they aligned with the trade unionists -

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): On a point of order. Is the hon. Member talking on the party issue or on the merger issue?

    Mr Speaker: I am just trying to pick up the threads of the hon. Lady's argument. I have not as yet come to the conclusion that she is very irrelevant.

What the Barisan Sosialis wish for is not in accordance with reality. They thought that if they aligned with the trade unionists, they could topple the P.A.P. Government and they could hold the posts of Prime Minister and Ministers. But their hopes were dashed to pieces. That is why they are now opposing us, saying that our merger proposal is a sort of sell-out.

    Mr Speaker: Order. It does seem to me now that the hon. Lady is going a little far away from the motion. Parts of this party strife, of course, are relevant but other parts are not.

    When the merger question was raised, they wanted to force us to resign so that they could have a general election. I feel that it was very mean of them to have indulged in these tactics. If they had the courage, they should have raised this question when they were in the Party. But since they dared not do this when they were in the Party, then they are the people who are wavering.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, let me ask them whether we are really selling out the people. We have never sold out the interests of the people. I feel that the question is one of either conditional or unconditional merger. The Members of the Opposition say that we are selling out the interests of the people. Let me state that all these merger proposals will have to be decided by the people of Singapore.

    Madam Hoe Puay Choo(In Mandarin): We know that the Minister for Home Affairs has introduced the Singapore National Referendum Bill. The people will then decide whether they accept our merger proposals. Yet the Barisan Sosialis accuse us of selling out the people. This is a groundless accusation. They claim that they have the overwhelming support of the people and that we have lost the confidence of the people.

But from the personal viewpoint, I believe there is something in the Chinese education policy which I cannot accept. Some of them are unreasonable. Complete merger as proposed by the Barisan Sosialis is, therefore, contradictory. I am Chinese, educated. I am now learning English. And if I were to answer Chinese question papers in English, I think it would be difficult for me. Similarly, if we accept the Federation education policy, many people in Singapore will resent it. Those heroes who are protecting Chinese education - what are they now? I believe their aim is just to embarrass us.

the field of labour. We have therefore suggested autonomy in labour in order to look after the privileges of the workers. If we do not make such a suggestion, then our ex-colleagues, i.e., the Barisan Sosialis members will accuse us of selling out the workers. They are bound to say this. They claim to represent the workers, and yet they want to accept the labour policy of the Federation. [Interruption]

If the Barisan Sosialis in Singapore and the Socialist Front in the Federation could both win some seats and formed a majority of representatives, then they could form their own government.     Mr S. T. Bani (Thomson): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is indeed regrettable that in a debate on such a major issue affecting the future of the people of Singapore, the Ministers of the P.A.P.
